column2: I knew all the current gossip about Mrs. Packard before I had parted with Miss Davies.
column3: I knew all the current gossip about mrs Packard before I had parted with Miss Davies.

column2: Her story was a simple one.
column3: Her story was a simple one.

column2: Bred in the West, she had come, immediately after her mother's death, to live with that mother's brother in Detroit.
column3: Bred in the West, she had come, immediately after her mother's death, to live with that mother's brother in Detroit.

column2: In doing this she had walked into a fortune.
column3: In doing this she had walked into a fortune.

column2: Her uncle was a rich man and when he died, which was about a year after her marriage with Mr. Packard and removal to C--, she found herself the recipient of an enormous legacy.
column3: Her uncle was a rich man and when he died, which was about a year after her marriage with mr Packard and removal to C-, she found herself the recipient of an enormous legacy.

column2: She was therefore a woman of independent means, an advantage which, added to personal attractions of a high order, and manners at once dignified and winning, caused her to be universally regarded as a woman greatly to be envied by all who appreciated a well-founded popularity.
column3: She was therefore a woman of independent means, an advantage which, added to personal attractions of a high order, and manners at once dignified and winning, caused her to be universally regarded as a woman greatly to be envied by all who appreciated a well founded popularity.

column3: So much for public opinion.

column2: It differs materially from that just given me by her husband.
column3: It differs materially from that just given me by her husband.

column2: The mayor lived on Franklin Street in a quarter I had seldom visited.
column3: The mayor lived on Franklin Street in a quarter I had seldom visited.

column2: As I entered this once aristocratic thoroughfare from Carlton Avenue, I was struck as I had been before by its heterogeneous appearance.
column3: As I entered this once aristocratic thoroughfare from Carlton Avenue, I was struck as I had been before by its heterogeneous appearance.

column2: Houses of strictly modern type neighbored those of a former period, and it was not uncommon to see mansion and hovel confronting each other from the opposite side of the street.
column3: Houses of strictly modern type neighbored those of a former period, and it was not uncommon to see mansion and hovel confronting each other from the opposite side of the street.

column2: Should I find the number I sought attached to one of the crude, unmeaning dwellings I was constantly passing, or to one of mellower aspect and possibly historic association?
column3: Should I find the number I sought attached to one of the crude, unmeaning dwellings I was constantly passing, or to one of mellower aspect and possibly historic association?

column2: I own that I felt a decided curiosity on this point, and congratulated myself greatly when I had left behind me a peculiarly obnoxious monstrosity in stone, whose imposing proportions might reasonably commend themselves to the necessities, if not to the taste of the city's mayor.
column3: I own that I felt a decided curiosity on this point, and congratulated myself greatly when I had left behind me a peculiarly obnoxious monstrosity in stone, whose imposing proportions might reasonably commend themselves to the necessities, if not to the taste of the city's mayor.

column2: A little shop, one story in height and old enough for its simple wooden walls to cry aloud for paint, stood out from the middle of a row of cheap brick houses.
column3: A little shop, one story in height and old enough for its simple wooden walls to cry aloud for paint, stood out from the middle of a row of cheap brick houses.

column2: Directly opposite it were two conspicuous dwellings, neither of them new and one of them ancient as the street itself.
column3: Directly opposite it were two conspicuous dwellings, neither of them new and one of them ancient as the street itself.

column2: They stood fairly close together, with an alley running between.
column3: They stood fairly close together, with an alley running between.

column2: From the number I had now reached it was evident that the mayor lived in one of these.
column3: From the number I had now reached it was evident that the mayor lived in one of these.

column2: Happily it was in the fresher and more inviting one.
column3: Happily it was in the fresher and more inviting one.

column2: As I noted this, I paused in admiration of its spacious front and imposing doorway. The latter was in the best style of Colonial architecture, and though raised but one step from the walk, was so distinguished by the fan-tailed light overhead and the flanking casements glazed with antique glass, that I felt myself carried back to the days when such domiciles were few and denoted wealth the most solid, and hospitality the most generous.
column3: As I noted this, I paused in admiration of its spacious front and imposing doorway. The latter was in the best style of Colonial architecture, and though raised but one step from the walk, was so distinguished by the fan tailed light overhead and the flanking casements glazed with antique glass, that I felt myself carried back to the days when such domiciles were few and denoted wealth the most solid, and hospitality the most generous.

column2: A light wall, painted to match the house, extended without break to the adjoining building, a structure equal to the other in age and dimensions, but differing in all other respects as much as neglect and misuse could make it.
column3: A light wall, painted to match the house, extended without break to the adjoining building, a structure equal to the other in age and dimensions, but differing in all other respects as much as neglect and misuse could make it.

column2: Gray and forbidding, it towered in its place, a perfect foil to the attractive dwelling whose single step I now amounted with cheerful composure.
column3: Gray and forbidding, it towered in its place, a perfect foil to the attractive dwelling whose single step I now amounted with cheerful composure.

column2: What should I have thought if at that moment I had been told that appearances were deceitful, and that there were many persons then living who, if left to their choice, would prefer life in the dismal walls from which I had instinctively turned, to a single night spent in the promising house I was so eager to enter.
column3: What should I have thought if at that moment I had been told that appearances were deceitful, and that there were many persons then living who, if left to their choice, would prefer life in the dismal walls from which I had instinctively turned, to a single night spent in the promising house I was so eager to enter.

column2: An old serving-man, with a countenance which struck me pleasantly enough at the time, opened the door in response to my ring, only to make instant way for Mayor Packard, who advanced from some near-by room to greet me.
column3: An old serving man, with a countenance which struck me pleasantly enough at the time, opened the door in response to my ring, only to make instant way for Mayor Packard, who advanced from some near by room to greet me.

column2: By this thoughtful attention I was spared the embarrassment from which I might otherwise have suffered.
column3: By this thoughtful attention I was spared the embarrassment from which I might otherwise have suffered.

column2: His few words of greeting set me entirely at my ease, and I was quite ready to follow him when a moment later he invited me to meet Mrs. Packard.
column3: His few words of greeting set me entirely at my ease, and I was quite ready to follow him when a moment later he invited me to meet mrs Packard.

column2: I can not promise you just the reception you naturally look for, said he, as he led me around the stairs toward an opening at their rear, "but she's a kind woman and can not but be struck with your own kind spirit and quiet manner."
column3: I can not promise you just the reception you naturally look for, said he, as he led me around the stairs toward an opening at their rear, "but she's a kind woman and can not but be struck with your own kind spirit and quiet manner."

column2: Happily, I was not called upon to answer, for at that moment the door swung open and he ushered me into a room flooded brilliantly with the last rays of the setting sun.
column3: Happily, I was not called upon to answer, for at that moment the door swung open and he ushered me into a room flooded brilliantly with the last rays of the setting sun

column2: The woman who sat in its glow made an instant and permanent impression upon me.
column3: The woman who sat in its glow made an instant and permanent impression upon me.

column2: No one could look intently upon her without feeling that here was a woman of individuality and power, overshadowed at present by the deepest melancholy.
column3: No one could look intently upon her without feeling that here was a woman of individuality and power, overshadowed at present by the deepest melancholy.

column2: As she rose and faced us I decided instantly that her husband had not exaggerated her state of mind.
column3: As she rose and faced us I decided instantly that her husband had not exaggerated her state of mind.

column2: Emotion of no ordinary nature disturbed the lines of her countenance and robbed her naturally fine figure of a goodly portion of its dignity and grace; and though she immediately controlled herself and assumed the imposing aspect of a highly trained woman, ready, if not eager, to welcome an intruding guest, I could not easily forget the drawn look about mouth and eyes which, in the first instant of our meeting, had distorted features naturally harmonious and beautifully serene.
column3: Emotion of no ordinary nature disturbed the lines of her countenance and robbed her naturally fine figure of a goodly portion of its dignity and grace; and though she immediately controlled herself and assumed the imposing aspect of a highly trained woman, ready, if not eager, to welcome an intruding guest, I could not easily forget the drawn look about mouth and eyes which, in the first instant of our meeting, had distorted features naturally harmonious and beautifully serene.

column3: But as Mayor Packard took no notice of him, knowing and expecting him to be there, no doubt, I, with a pardonable confusion, withdrew my eyes from the handsomest face I had ever seen, and, noting that my employer had stopped before a type writer's table, I took my place at his side, without knowing very well what this move meant or what he expected me to do there.

column2: I thought it was a passing mood at the time; she is a sensitive woman and she had been reading--I saw the book lying on the floor at her side; but when, having recovered from her dejection--a dejection, mind you, which she would neither acknowledge nor explain--she accompanied me out to dinner, she showed even more feeling on our return, shrinking unaccountably from leaving the carriage and showing, not only in this way but in others, a very evident distaste to reenter her own house. Now, whatever hold I still retain upon her is of so slight a nature that I am afraid every day she will leave me."
